messages.content: ComfyUI-BrushNet is a custom node for ComfyUI that allows users to inpaint images using the Brushnet model, as described in the paper 'BrushNet: A Plug-and-Play Image Inpainting Model with Decomposed Dual-Branch Diffusion'.

To install ComfyUI-BrushNet, you need to clone the repo into the custom_nodes directory and install the requirements using the commands 'git clone https://github.com/nullquant/ComfyUI-BrushNet.git' and 'pip install -r requirements.txt'.
Where can I download the checkpoints for BrushNet?

Checkpoints for BrushNet can be downloaded from [here](https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1fqmS1CEOvXCxNWFrsSYd_jHYXxrydh1n?usp=drive_link). Both 'segmentation_mask_brushnet_ckpt' and 'random_mask_brushnet_ckpt' should be placed inside 'models/inpaint/brushnet' folder.
What is the intended workflow for using ComfyUI-BrushNet?

An example for the intended workflow can be found in the 'example' directory as a json file named 'BrushNet_example.json'. Additionally, a visual representation of the workflow can be found in the 'example' directory under the name 'BrushNet_example.png'.
What are the known bugs in ComfyUI-BrushNet?

There are two known bugs. Firstly, the nodes use a custom 'diffusers' library which can potentially conflict with other custom nodes. Secondly, the 'BrushNetPipeline' sometimes freezes on loading. The creators are looking into this problem.
I contributed to the ComfyUI adaptation of the tool, but the authors of the paper 'BrushNet: A Plug-and--Play Image Inpainting Model with Decomposed Dual-Branch Diffusion' deserve the credit.
Which base model should be used with ComfyUI-BrushNet?
The base model should be of SD1.5 type. An example is 'realisticVisionV60B1_v51VAE'.
